xf:input.xf:label: PREGNANCY STATUS
xf:input.xf:hint: Question on encounter form: "Is the patient pregnant?"

xf:input.xf:label: LAST MENSTRUAL PERIOD DATE
xf:input.xf:hint: By convention, pregnancies are dated in weeks starting from the first day of a woman's last menstrual period (LMP). If her menstrual periods are regular and ovulation occurs on day 14 of her cycle, conception takes place about 2 weeks after her LMP. A woman is therefore considered to be 6 weeks pregnant 2 weeks after her first missed period. A woman's obstetric date is different from the embryologic date (the age of the embryo). The obstetric date is about 2 weeks longer than the embryologic date.

xf:select.xf:label: URINE PREGNANCY TEST, QUALITATIVE
xf:select.xf:hint: Test that determines pregnancy status through measure of hormone content in urine.

By convention, pregnancies are dated in weeks starting from the first day of a woman's last menstrual period (LMP). If her menstrual periods are regular and ovulation occurs on day 14 of her cycle, conception takes place about 2 weeks after her LMP. A woman is therefore considered to be 6 weeks pregnant 2 weeks after her first missed period. A woman's obstetric date is different from the embryologic date (the age of the embryo). The obstetric date is about 2 weeks longer than the embryologic date.

text.value: By convention, pregnancies are dated in weeks starting from the first day of a woman's last menstrual period (LMP). If her menstrual periods are regular and ovulation occurs on day 14 of her cycle, conception takes place about 2 weeks after her LMP. A woman is therefore considered to be 6 weeks pregnant 2 weeks after her first missed period. A woman's obstetric date is different from the embryologic date (the age of the embryo). The obstetric date is about 2 weeks longer than the embryologic date.
Question on encounter form: "Is the patient pregnant?"

By convention, pregnancies are dated in weeks starting from the first day of a woman's last menstrual period (LMP). If her menstrual periods are regular and ovulation occurs on day 14 of her cycle, conception takes place about 2 weeks after her LMP. A woman is therefore considered to be 6 weeks pregnant 2 weeks after her first missed period. A woman's obstetric date is different from the embryologic date (the age of the embryo). The obstetric date is about 2 weeks longer than the embryologic date.
An estimation of the date in which a mother will give birth to her child. [5596]
Is the patient enrolled in Antenatal Care Service?
Test that determines pregnancy status through measure of hormone content in urine.
Does the patient sleep under a mosquito net at night?
Did insecticide treated net issue this visit?
A question to collect the number of condoms given. The unit is " Condoms". [8706]
